mfm.io package¶

Submodules¶

mfm.io.ascii module¶

class mfm.io.ascii.Csv(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

Csv is a class to handle coma separated value files.

Parameters:kwargs –

Examples

Two-column data

>>> import mfm.io.ascii
>>> csv = mfm.io.ascii.Csv()
>>> filename = './sample_data/ibh/Decay_577D.txt'
>>> csv.load(filename)
>>> csv.data_x
array([  1.00000000e+00,   2.00000000e+00,   3.00000000e+00, ...,
 4.09400000e+03,   4.09500000e+03,   4.09600000e+03])
 >>> csv.data_y
 array([ 0.,  0.,  0., ...,  0.,  0.,  0.])
 >>> max(csv.data_y)
 50010.0

One-column Jordi data

>>> csv = mfm.io.ascii.Csv()
>>> filename = './sample_data/Jordi/02_18-577+7.5uM(577)UP_8ps.dat'
>>> csv.load(filename)
>>> csv.data_x
array([  1.00000000e+00,   2.00000000e+00,   3.00000000e+00, ...,
 4.09400000e+03,   4.09500000e+03,   4.09600000e+03])
 >>> csv.data_y
 array([ 0.,  0.,  0., ...,  0.,  0.,  0.])
 >>> max(csv.data_y)
 50010.0
data¶

Numpy array of the data

data_x¶

The x-values of the loaded file as numpy.array

data_y¶

The y-values of the loaded file as numpy.array

error_x¶

The errors of the x-values of the loaded file as numpy.array

error_y¶

The errors of the y-values of the loaded file as numpy.array

filename¶

The currently open filename (after setting this parameter the file is opened)

header¶

A list of the column headers

load(filename, skiprows=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

This method loads a filename to the Csv object :param filename: string specifying the file :param skiprows: number of rows to skip in the file. By default the value of the instance is used :param verbose: The method is verbose if verbose is set to True of the verbose attribute of the instance is True.

n_cols¶

The number of columns

n_points¶

The number of data points corresponds to the number of rows :py:attribute`.CSV.n_rows`

n_rows¶

The number of rows

reload_csv()[source]¶

Reloads the csv as specified by :py:attribute:`.CSV.filename`

save(data, filename, delimiter='\t', mode='txt')[source]¶

Saves data x, y to file in format (csv). x and y should have the same lenght.

Parameters:
  • filename – string Target filename
  • x – array
  • y – array
  • verbose – bool
  • fmt –

mfm.io.pdb.read(filename, assignCharge=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

Open pdb_file and read each line into pdb (a list of lines)

Parameters:filename –
Returns:numpy structured array containing the PDB info and VdW-radii and charges

Examples

>>> import mfm
>>> pdb_file = './sample_data/model/hgbp1/hGBP1_closed.pdb'
>>> pdb = mfm.io.pdb_file.read(pdb_file, verbose=True)
>>> pdb[:5]
array([ (0, ' ', 7, 'MET', 1, 'N', 'N', [72.739, -17.501, 8.879], 0.0, 1.65, 0.0, 14.0067),
       (1, ' ', 7, 'MET', 2, 'CA', 'C', [73.841, -17.042, 9.747], 0.0, 1.76, 0.0, 12.0107),
       (2, ' ', 7, 'MET', 3, 'C', 'C', [74.361, -18.178, 10.643], 0.0, 1.76, 0.0, 12.0107),
       (3, ' ', 7, 'MET', 4, 'O', 'O', [73.642, -18.708, 11.489], 0.0, 1.4, 0.0, 15.9994),
       (4, ' ', 7, 'MET', 5, 'CB', 'C', [73.384, -15.89, 10.649], 0.0, 1.76, 0.0, 12.0107)],
      dtype=[('i', '<i4'), ('chain', 'S1'), ('res_id', '<i4'), ('res_name', 'S5'), ('atom_id', '<i4'), ('atom_name', 'S5
'), ('element', 'S1'), ('coord', '<f8', (3,)), ('charge', '<f8'), ('radius', '<f8'), ('bfactor', '<f8'), ('mass', '<f8')
])
mfm.io.pdb.sequence(structure)[source]¶
mfm.io.pdb.write(filename, atoms=None, append_model=False, append_coordinates=False)[source]¶

Writes a structured numpy array containing the PDB-info to a PDB-file

If append_model and append_coordinates are False the file is overwritten. Otherwise the atomic-coordinates are appended to the existing file.

Parameters:
  • filename – target-filename
  • atoms – structured numpy array
  • append_model – bool If True the atoms are appended as a new model
  • append_coordinates – If True the coordinates are appended to the file
mfm.io.pdb.write_xyz(filename, points, verbose=False)[source]¶

Writes the points as xyz-format file. The xyz-format file can be opened and displayed for instance in PyMol

Parameters:
  • filename – string
  • points – array
  • verbose – bool

mfm.io.photons module¶

class mfm.io.photons.Photons(p_object, file_type=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

Parameters:
  • p_object – Is either a list of filenames or a single string containing the path to one file. If the first argument is n
  • file_type – The file type of the files passed using the first argument (p_object) is specified using the ‘file_type’ parameter. This string is either ‘hdf’ or ‘bh132’, ‘bh630_x48’, ‘ht3’, ‘iss’. If the file type is not an hdf file the files are temporarily converted to hdf-files to guarantee a consistent interface.
  • kwargs –
Returns:

Examples

>>> import glob
>>> import mfm
>>> directory = "../sample_data/tttr/spc132/smDNA"
>>> spc_files = glob.glob(directory+'/*.spc')
>>> photons = mfm.io.photons.Photons(spc_files, file_type="bh132")
>>> print photons
File-type: bh132
Filename(s):
        ./sample_data/tttr/spc132/hGBP1_18D\m000.spc
        ./sample_data/tttr/spc132/hGBP1_18D\m001.spc
        ./sample_data/tttr/spc132/hGBP1_18D\m002.spc
        ./sample_data/tttr/spc132/hGBP1_18D\m003.spc
nTAC:   4095
nROUT:  255
MTCLK [ms]:     1.36000003815e-05

>>> print photons[:10]
File-type: None
Filename(s):    None
nTAC:   4095
nROUT:  255
MTCLK [ms]:     1.36000003815e-05

take(keys)[source]¶
mfm.io.photons.read_BIDs(filenames, stack_files=True)[source]¶

Reads Seidel-BID files and returns a list of numpy arrays. Each numpy array contains the indexes of the photons of the burst. These indexes can be used to slice a photon-stream.

Seidel BID-files only contain the first and the last photon of the Burst and not all photons of the burst. Thus, the Seidel BID-files have to be converted to array-type objects containing all photons of the burst to be able to use standard Python slicing syntax to select photons.

Parameters:
  • filenames – filename pointing to a Seidel BID-file
  • stack – bool If stack is True the returned list is stacked and the numbering of the bursts is made continuous. This is the default behavior.
Returns:

Examples

>>> import mfm, glob
>>> directory = "./sample_data/tttr/spc132/hGBP1_18D/burstwise_All 0.1200#30\BID"
>>> files = glob.glob(directory+'/*.bst')
>>> bids = mfm.io.photons.read_BIDs(files)
>>> bids[1]
array([20384, 20385, 20386, 20387, 20388, 20389, 20390, 20391, 20392,
   20393, 20394, 20395, 20396, 20397, 20398, 20399, 20400, 20401,
   20402, 20403, 20404, 20405, 20406, 20407, 20408, 20409, 20410,

mfm.io.sdtfile module¶

Read Becker & Hickl SDT files.

SDT files are produced by Becker & Hickl SPCM software. They contain time correlated single photon counting instrumentation parameters and measurement data. Currently only the “Setup & Data” and “FCS Data” formats are supported.

Becker & Hickl GmbH is a manufacturer of equipment for photon counting.

Author:Christoph Gohlke
Organization:Laboratory for Fluorescence Dynamics, University of California, Irvine
Version:2014.09.05

Requirements¶

  • CPython 2.7 or 3.4
  • Numpy 1.8.2

Revisions¶

2014.09.05
Fixed reading multiple MEASURE_INFO records.

Notes¶

The API is not stable yet and might change between revisions.

The Priithon package includes an alternative SDT file reader.

References¶

  1. W Becker. The bh TCSPC Handbook. Third Edition. Becker & Hickl GmbH 2008. pp 401.
  2. SPC_data_file_structure.h header file. Part of the Becker & Hickl SPCM software.

Examples¶

>>> sdt = SdtFile("image.sdt")
>>> sdt.header.revision
588
>>> sdt.info.id[1:-1]
b'SPC Setup & Data File'
>>> int(sdt.measure_info.scan_x)
128
>>> sdt.data[0].shape
(128, 128, 256)
>>> sdt.times[0].shape
(256,)

>>> sdt = SdtFile("fluorescein.sdt")
>>> len(sdt.data)
4
>>> sdt.data[3].shape
(1, 1024)

>>> sdt = SdtFile("fcs.sdt")
>>> sdt.info.id[1:-1]
b'SPC FCS Data File'
>>> sdt.data[0].shape
(512, 512, 256)
class mfm.io.sdtfile.SdtFile(arg=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Becker & Hickl SDT file.

Attributes

header (numpy.rec.array of FILE_HEADER structure) General information about the location of the setup and measurement data within the file.
info (FileInfo) General information in ASCII format.
setup (SetupBlock) Setup block containing all system parameters, display parameters, etc.
measure_info (numpy.rec.array of MEASURE_INFO structure) Measurement description blocks.
block_headers (list of numpy.rec.array of BLOCK_HEADER structure) Data block headers.
data (list of 2D numpy arrays) Photon counts at each curve point.
times (list of 1D numpy arrays) Time axes for each data set.
block_measure_info(block)[source]¶

Return measure_info record for data block.

mfm.io.tttr module¶

mfm.io.tttr.bh123_header(b)[source]¶
mfm.io.tttr.bh132_photons(b, invert_tac=True)[source]¶

Get the macro-time, micro-time and the routing channel number of a BH132-file contained in a binary numpy-array of 8-bit chars.

Parameters:b – numpy-array a numpy array of chars containing the binary information of a BH132-file
Returns:list a list containing the number of photons, numpy-array of macro-time (64-bit unsigned integers), numpy-array of TAC-values (32-bit unsigned integers), numpy-array of channel numbers (8-bit unsigned integers)
mfm.io.tttr.ht3_header(b)[source]¶
mfm.io.tttr.ht3_photons(b)[source]¶

Get the macro-time, micro-time and the routing channel number of a PQ-HT3-file (version 1) contained in a binary numpy-array of 8-bit chars.

Parameters:b – numpy-array a numpy array of chars containing the binary information of a BH132-file
Returns:list a list containing the number of photons, numpy-array of macro-time (64-bit unsigned integers), numpy-array of TAC-values (32-bit unsigned integers), numpy-array of channel numbers (8-bit unsigned integers)

hdf-file handle (pytables)
mfm.io.tttr.read_header(binary, routine_name)[source]¶

Reads the header-information of binary TTTR-files. The TTTR-files have to be passed as numpy array of type numpy.uint8

Parameters:
  • binary – A numpy array containing the data of the SPC or HT3 files
  • routine_name – either bh132 or ht3
Returns:

An dictionary containing the most important header data.

Examples

Reading Seidel-BID files

>>> import glob, mfm
>>> directory = "./sample_data/tttr/spc132/hGBP1_18D"
>>> spc_files = glob.glob(directory+'/*.spc')
>>> b = np.fromfile(spc_files[0], dtype=np.uint8)
>>> header = mfm.io.photons.read_header(b, 'bh132')
>>> print header
{'MTCLK': 13.6, 'DINV': 0, 'nEvents': 1200000}
mfm.io.tttr.spc2hdf(spc_files, routine_name='bh132', **kwargs)[source]¶

Converts BH-SPC files into hdf file format

Parameters:
  • spc_files – list A list of spc-files
  • routine_name – Name of the used reading routine by default “bh132” alternatively “bh630_x48”
  • verbose – bool By default False
  • kwargs – If the parameter ‘filename’ is not provided only a temporary hdf (.h5) file is created If the parameter ‘title’ is provided the data is stored in the hdf-group provided by the parameter ‘title. Otherwise the default ‘title’ spc is used to store the data within the HDF-File.
Returns:

tables.file.File

Examples

If the HDF-File doesn’t exist it will be created

>>> import mfm
>>> import glob
>>> directory = "./sample_data/tttr/spc132/hGBP1_18D"
>>> spc_files = glob.glob(directory+'/*.spc')
>>> h5 = mfm.io.photons.spc2hdf(spc_files, filename='test.h5', title='hGBP1_18D')

To an existing HDF-File simply a new group with the title will be created

>>> h5 = mfm.io.photons.spc2hdf(spc_files, filename='test.h5', title='hGBP1_18D_2')

After finished work with the HDF-File it should be closed.

>>> h5.close()

Module contents¶

The mfm.io module contains all classes, functions and modules relevant for file input and outputs. In particular three kinds of file-types are handled:

  1. Comma-separated files mfm.io.csv_file
  2. PDB-file mfm.io.pdb_file
  3. TTTR-files containing photon data mfm.io.photons
